bibl.title: Letter from A.S. von Mansfelde to Mabel H. Lazear, September 26, 1907

div1.p: Von Mansfelde informs Mabel Lazear that Carroll has died. He discusses work to increase her pension.

div1.head: Letter from A.S. von Mansfelde to Mabel H. Lazear, September 26, 1907
div1.opener:
Nebraska State Medical Association
A. S. v. Mansfelde, M. D. Treasurer
“Quality Hill,” Ashland, Nebraska
September 26th 1907.
No. 2670.
Mrs Mabel Lazear:
Santa Barbara. Cal.
My dear Mrs Lazear:
div1.p:
Of course, you have already learned
from the press that poor Carroll is gone
to his reward. He died September 16th and
was burried Sept 18th in afternoon. He, poor
fellow, never donned his uniform! I would
have written sooner, but I could not do it.
Besides I was waiting for a letter from my
own Congressman concerning your affairs
and here is what, among other things he
writes me:

“Yes, I shall be pleased to
aid the Lazears, I expect to come to
Ashland before long. I can't say just
when, and will go over the matter with
you. It is a worthy proposition...... I
desire also to talk to you about the com-
mittee, to which it (the bill) will be re-
ferred.”

Thus I shall have what I planned.
Nebraska State Medical Association
A. S. v. Mansfelde, M. D. Treasurer
“Quality Hill,” Ashland, Nebraska
No.---------------------
I do not want to offend the Merchants
Association of New York,- who offered me
to have one of their N.Y. congressmen to
look after the matter, neither will I offend
the physician members of the House
by letting my own Congressman do what
I want done. Besides Congressman
Hinshaw is a personal friend, who will
keep me fully posted, hence in touch with
what is going on at Washington -- and
he has promised to see the bill passed;
not simply to introduce it. I told him
I could get scores to do that. I think
now of suggesting Sen. Knox to him for
your bill and Senator Dick for Mrs
Carrolls bill -- but, of course, if he prefers
his own friends in the Senate to look
after the measures, they will be the ones
to attend to it. So you see, I am not
putting things off: I shall be more than
ready when Congress meets.

Did you forget the sending of Dr.
Lazear's picture?

Give my love to the children.
Tell them: when their mother gets a
big pension, I expect to see them
someday. In the meantime believe
me as ever
div1.closer:
Very sincerely your friend ASMansfelde After Mr Hinshaw's visit to me I
will write you again.
ASM.
